text: Robert Jarratt Crosthwaite (13 October 1837, Wellington, Somerset9 September 1925, Bolton Percy) was the inaugural Bishop of Beverley in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.BoB web-site Born in Wellington, Somerset, on 13 October 1837,DOB/DOD Robert Crosthwaite was the son of Benjamin Crosthwaite, priest and canon.“Who was Who”1897-1990 London, A & C Black, 1991 He was educated at Leeds Grammar School School History and Trinity College, Cambridge. Ordained in 1862, he began his career with a curacy at North Cave after which he was Domestic Chaplain to the Archbishop of York. Following incumbencies in Brayton and York he was Rector of Bolton PercyMaterials within The National Archives (1885–1923) and appointed Archdeacon of York in 1884. Five years later he became a Suffragan Bishop to assist within the Diocese of York and served to 1923. He was consecrated a bishop on 11 June 1889, by William Thomson, Archbishop of York, at York Minster. He became a Doctor of Divinity; and died on 9 September 1925 at Bolton Percy.The Times, Friday, 11 September 1925; p. 14; Issue 44064; col C Obituary- Bishop Crosthwaite ==References== ==External links== * Category:1837 births Category:People from Wellington, Somerset Category:People educated at Leeds Grammar School Category:Fellows of Trinity College, Cambridge Category:1925 deaths Category:Archdeacons of York Category:19th-century Anglican bishops Category:20th-century Anglican bishops Category:Bishops of Beverley
